name: Congresswoman Cheri Bustos
subject: Improving rural health care.

I also announced $4.5 million worth of funding to modernize and expand outdated locks and dams on the Upper Mississippi and Illinois Rivers.    Congresswoman Bustos signing legislation to create the Rural Health Liaison.  Health care is the number one issue I hear about from folks back home and in rural communities, access to care can present unique challenges. That’s why I was proud that on Friday the USDA appointed the first-ever Rural Health Liaison after I passed legislation to create the role. It’s crucial we ensure small towns across the Heartland have access to 21st Century health care and that’s what this position will help do. I remain committed to lowering health care costs and improving access, and I look forward to working with our first Rural Health Liaison. You can learn more here.  Then, I joined Senators Durbin and Duckworth to announce $4.5 million worth of funding to improve our locks and dams along the Upper Mississippi and Illinois Rivers. Our inland waterways are responsible for moving more than 600 million tons of goods each year, including agricultural products, but outdated locks and dams could bring this local economic driver to a standstill. This funding will help increase our region’s competitive edge, promote efficiency and support our local economy. Read more about it here.  Finally, I was proud to vote in favor of women’s equality when I helped pass a bipartisan resolution to remove the arbitrary deadline Congress previously set to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. With this vote, we take another step forward to guarantee fundamental rights for all and place the ERA on a path to becoming a part of our Constitution.  Until next time, Cheri                                     Please don't reply to this email. If you have any questions, comments, or would like to contact Cheri, please visit the . name: Congressman Buddy Carter
subject: A Big Week for the Port of Savannah
body: A BIG WEEK FOR THE PORT OF SAVANNAH President Trump released his fiscal year 2021 budget this week. The budget proposal is pro-worker, pro-family, pro-growth and pro-American. The President's budget also includes great news for the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project (SHEP). The budget includes full funding to keep the project on track. This is the fourth year in a row SHEP will receive full federal funding from the Trump Administration, pending Congressional passage of the annual appropriations bill. President Trump has again proven that the Trump administration understands the critical importance of the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project for our nation. The project is now well past the half way mark. While the finish line is finally in sight, I will continue to fight tirelessly for this federal support and to ensure the project is completed. Also this week, I announced that we secured a federal Department of Transportation grant of $34,600,000.00 for the Port of Savannah. The Port Infrastructure Development Grant is critical to straighten and realign Berth 1, one of the oldest areas of the Port, to increase efficiency. The funding will work to modernize the Berths to handle larger ships. This grant is necessary to ensure the Port is able to handle additional cargo. This announcement goes hand-in-hand with recent news, including the recent land acquisition, to increase port capacity and efficiency. I am excited that this federal funding will work to modernize the port, allow larger ships and increase the amount of cargo they will be able to move. I discussed President Trump's budget and the blockbuster week for the Port of Savannah in this week's edition of Buddy's Briefing. Click here to watch Buddy's Briefing FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CCLIII Monday, February 10, 2020: After an early morning flight back to Washington, Im in the House Chamber where I pay tribute to one of my favorite veterans, Paul Grassey from Savannah. Paul, a World War II veteran who is also a great singer and routinely leads us in patriotic songs at veterans events, has recently been given the French governments highest possible honor, the Legion of Honor, for his military service and role in helping to free France from Nazi occupation. A link to my tribute can be found here. Once back in my office, we have our weekly all district conference call to discuss last weeks events in the district, upcoming events and casework. Later, I have a series of phone interviews to discuss President Trumps fiscal year 2021 budget proposal that was released today and includes full funding for the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project (SHEP) for the fourth straight year. Funding this project was one of my top priorities when I took office five years ago and this good news should allow us to complete dredging by the end of 2021 or the beginning of 2022. My first interview is with WTOC TV in Savannah, followed by the Savannah Morning News (SMN) and WJCL TV in Savannah. A link to these stories can be found here, here and here. After our weekly DC staff briefing, I head to our weekly Whip Team meeting before heading to the House Chamber for our first vote series of the week. My final event of the day is a National Security Intelligence Forum hosted by House Intelligence Committee Ranking Member Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) where we hear from United States Deputy National Security Advisor Matt Pottinger. Tuesday, February 11, 2020: Im honored this morning to receive the Family Research Councils (FRC) True Blue Award in recognition of my perfect 100% score on the FRC Action 2019 Vote Scorecard. FRC is a Christian public policy ministry that defends religious liberty, the unborn and families. Rep. Carter receives the Family Research Council's True Blue Award Afterwards, I head to our weekly GOP Conference before heading to an Energy and Commerce (E&C) Consumer Protection and Commerce (CPAC) Subcommittee hearing on autonomous vehicles. A link to my questions can be found here. After I return to my office for a meeting with my good friend and former Georgia State Senate colleague, Cecil Staton, who is now President and CEO of the Asian American Hotel Owners Association (AAHOA), I head to an E&C Environment Subcommittee hearing on the Environmental Protection Agencys (EPA) lead and copper proposal. Once back in my office, I have a phone interview with WSAV TV in Savannah to discuss SHEP funding. A link to this interview can be found here. The good news on the Port of Savannah keeps coming as we find out today that we have secured a $34.6 million Department of Transportation (DOT) grant that will allow us to straighten and realign one of the oldest parts of the Port to accommodate larger ships. Before heading to the House Chamber for our first and only vote series of the day, I have a phone interview with the SMN to discuss the grant. A link to the story can be found here. After votes, I remain in the House Chamber where I memorialize Ann Cox Chambers who recently passed. A link to my tribute can be found here. Rep. Carter meeting with a delegation from the Federal Bureau of Prisons Once back in my office, I have a meeting with the Georgia Special Olympics delegation followed by a meeting with the Director of the National Center for Advancing Translational Scientists (NCATS) at the National Institutes of Health (NIH). Next, I meet with a delegation from the Federal Bureau of Prisons before having an on-camera interview with WTOC TV in Savannah to discuss the DOT grant for the Port of Savannah. A link to my interview can be found here. Wednesday, February 12, 2020: Im up early this morning and head to downtown Washington with Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) as we meet with CEOs of pharmaceutical manufacturers to discuss the prescription drug pricing bills being considered in Congress. Once back at the Capitol, I head to a GOP policy conference where we discuss the threats posed by China and hear from experts in the field. Afterwards, I head to the House Chamber where I pay tribute to Clermont Huger Lee and Suzanne Shank who are being honored by the Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD) as Women of Vision, Dr. Freddie Smith, who has retired as the Senior Pastor at Sweat Memorial Baptist Church in Waycross, and the Savannah Art Association on celebrating their 100th anniversary. A link to my tributes can be found here, here, here and here. Next, I head to an E&C Health Subcommittee meeting on abortion. A link to my comments can be found here. Once back in my office, I meet with my good friends Bill Eley and Mike James to discuss pharmacy issues before heading to the conservative Republican Study Committee (RSC) meeting. Before heading back to my office, I attend an all member briefing on the coronavirus where we get up to date information. Once back at my office, I have a series of meetings beginning with the Girl Scouts National CEO and followed by a Future Leaders Exchange (FLEX) student from the country of Georgia who is staying with a family in Effingham County. Rep. Carter meeting with Habitat for Humanity International After meeting with representatives from Habitat for Humanity International, I meet with members of the American Federation of Government Employees before having a phone interview with the Brunswick News to discuss the Golden Ray removal operation. Next, I head to the House Chamber for a long vote series that includes nine votes before heading back to my office where I have a telephone town hall with special guest Rep. Rob Woodall (R-GA), a member of the Budget and Transportation and Infrastructure (T&I) Committees. Before calling it a day, I head to the T&I Committee room where I film this weeks edition of Buddys Briefings. Thursday, February 13, 2020: Having owned my own business for over 30 years, Ive had many associates come and go. While youre always glad to see someone better themselves, many are difficult to replace. After an early morning meeting with leadership to discuss election issues, I spend the next few hours in my office interviewing candidates for our health care legislative assistant position. Fortunately, because I serve on the E&C Healthcare Subcommittee, top candidates are attracted to our office and we have quality interviews. After filming a quick video to promote our open house next Wednesday, February 19th, at our new Brunswick district office location, I head to the House Chamber for our only vote series of the day before heading to the airport for my return trip home. Friday, February 14, 2020: After getting a few hours of sleep last night, Im up early for my Band of Brothers bible study in Garden City this morning and afterwards head down to St. Simons Island where I have the pleasure of visiting St. Simons Christian School.  Rep. Carter visiting St. Simons Christian School Ive always said that interacting with students is my favorite part of serving in this position and today is another example why. What a great group of students! Because it is a small school, I get to visit each classroom from pre-K through 5th and then meet with the 6th through 8th grade classes as a group. They ask great questions and I thoroughly enjoy my visit. Afterwards, I head to Sea Island where my good friend, Jonathan RacIin, has assembled an outstanding group of community leaders for a round table discussion on national and world issues. Next, I head back to Savannah and during the drive I have a phone interview with WJAX TV in Jacksonville for an update on the Golden Ray removal project in the Brunswick Harbor.  Rep. Carter at the SCAD Savannah Women of Vision Once back in Savannah, I head to Arnold Hall, home of the Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD) School of Liberal Arts, for a ceremony celebrating Savannah Women of Vision. The two 2020 honorees, Clermont Huger Lee and Suzanne Shank, join an elite group of trailblazers whose remarkable ideas, insightful leadership and distinguished service have had a major impact on the City of Savannah. My last stop of yet another busy week is to Tybee Island where the Two Hundred Club of the Coastal Empire is hosting a benefit. This great organization helps provide for the surviving spouses and dependents of law enforcement officers, firefighters and paramedics who lose their lives in the line of duty. Bost                  The Bost Bulletin Friend,  As we celebrate Presidents' Day tomorrow, it's important to note the impact each president has had on our nation's history, including Illinois' own Abraham Lincoln. His dedication to freedom is a shining example of the values our country represents. Here's what I've been up to this week.   Protecting Our Children in Schools Having the Securing Our Schools Act, a bill I introduced, signed into law by the President is one of my proudest achievements while serving in Congress. This law created the School Violence Prevention Program (SVPP) to provide law enforcement with the appropriate tools and technology they need to make classrooms safer. Starting this week, the SVPP is accepting applications through April 8, 2020 for this year’s round of grant funding. For more information, please visit here. As a former first responder, I encourage local government leaders, school administrators, and law enforcement to apply ASAP!  Safeguarding Veteran Votes Ensuring Americans have a say in who leads our government is a right our veterans overseas fight for every day. Too often, however, our men and women serving across the world are unable to have their absentee ballots arrive to the States on time for the collection deadline.This is completely unacceptable, which is why I am proud to tell you that I have cosponsored the Counting All Military Votes Act to improve voting accessibility for American active duty service members. Our military men and women overseas are committed to keeping American diplomats and citizens safe and deserve peace of mind knowing that their ballot will be counted in a timely manner.     Empowering the Postal Service Since its creation in 1775, the USPS has remained one of the most reliable government agencies. In fact, it is one of the few explicitly mentioned in the United States Constitution. Today, the USPS employs over 600,000 workers and continues to be an integral function of our government and economy. However, due to a mandate passed over a decade ago, the USPS is obligated to pre-fund its future pensions, losing the agency millions of dollars every year. I'm proud to tell you that legislation I cosponsored, the USPS Fairness Act, passed the House last week. This bill will make sure that employees within the USPS will receive the same retiree health funding benefits that apply to all other federal agencies and allow the USPS to invest in itself for the first time in years.  Prior to its passage, I spoke on the House Floor in support of this legislation. To hear my remarks, please click the link below.     Sending Valentines for Veterans On Thursday, I joined my colleagues in writing Valentine's Day messages to be sent to veterans living in the Washington, D.C. area. Veterans selflessly signed up to defend the freedoms of our great country without asking for anything in return. As a Marine and father of a Marine, I was honored to take part in this small gesture of appreciation for those who have served our nation.    Protecting Correctional Officers Our district is home to United States Penitentiary Marion, but like many facilities, it is not staffed at the proper level. Studies show that understaffed facilities have more assaults against workers and more inmate suicides. Recently, I led a letter asking the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to provide the Bureau of Prisons with direct-hiring authority, which would allow individual facilities to hire the staff they need on their own timelines. This week, I was honored to accept the Legislative Appreciation Award from the Council of Prison Locals for my work on this issue and will continue to make sure the safety of correctional facility staff and inmates is a top priority.      Investing in Illinois Waterways I met with Illinois members of the Waterways Council to discuss the funding and maintenance of our system of inland waterways and ports. With millions of tons of cargo transported on the Mississippi River every year, this issue is one of my top priorities. As a member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I will continue to make sure Southern Illinois's waterways are taken care of.     Meeting with Southern Illinois Community Colleges Earlier in the week, I had the chance to meet with Interim President Dr. Kathleen Curphy and Don Patton with Shawnee Community College as well as several administrators and trustees from John A. Logan Community College to discuss access to grants, lowering costs of tuition, and bolstering job training for career and technical education (CTE) programs. As a member of the Congressional CTE Caucus, I will continue to support these critically important programs.   It was a productive week here in Washington, with a schedule jam-packed full of meeting with folks from across our district. I’m looking forward being back in Southern Illinois for our district work week.  I hope you enjoy Presidents' Day tomorrow and are able to relax and reflect on the blessings in your life. Enjoy your week!  -Mike                  Unsubscribe

It has been a busy two weeks in Washington! I appreciate you taking the time to read my E-Newsletter to stay up-to-date on everything happening in the House of Representatives and back in the district.               President Trump Delivers State of the Union Address   Last week, President Trump laid out a bold vision forward for our country and highlighted the numerous successes of his administration. Our nation has truly experienced a blue-collar boom, with strong year-over-year wage growth and record low unemployment.                             Vice President Pence Visits Lancaster!  It was great to join Vice President Mike Pence for a community leaders roundtable in Lancaster and to hear directly from the people their thoughts about what is happening in Washington. Thanks for the lift back to Washington, aboard Air Force 2!                                       National Prayer Breakfast  It was great to join so many for the National Prayer Breakfast last week. I had the honor of being joined by Pastor Matt Mylin and his wife Kelly, who lead the congregation at the Worship Center in Leola, PA. The morning featured an uplifting message from keynote speaker Arthur Brooks.                                                    From the Floor    This past week, I had the opportunity to speak from the floor of the House to honor two community leaders and to oppose legislation which would harm American workers.  I spoke out against the PRO Act, which is a massive giveaway to union special interests and would have drastically changed the balance of labor laws in favor of unions and against American workers. Click here to watch my remarks on the PRO Act. Additionally, I spoke on the House floor to honor the life of Mr. Robert Aichele, a community leader in Lancaster County, who passed away at the age of 92 last week. Click here to watch my comments honoring the memory of Mr. Aichele.  I also spoke on the House floor to give thanks to Dr. William Griscom, who has recently retired after serving as President of Thaddeus Stevens College of Technology for 23 years. Thousands of lives across south central Pennsylvania have been put on the path to success because of his leadership. Click here to watch my remarks thanking Dr. William Griscom.                              $5 Million Saved for PA-11 Constituents  It was an honor to be able to announce earlier this week, that my office has saved over $5 million for constituents of Pennsylvania’s 11th Congressional District. Since taking office in 2017, my office has closed over 4,000 cases to assist individuals with difficulty they may be experiencing with federal agencies. Click here to learn more about this great milestone!  And click here, if my office can assist you with an issue you’re experiencing with the federal government!                                             Visits to Washington!  It was great to be visited by John Fiorill in my Washington, DC office this week. John is the Second Vice President of the Pennsylvania Fraternal Order of Police, and the former Chief of the Southern Regional Police Department. Thanks for visiting!                                                      Here’s Lloyd  Since I’ve taken office, I’ve held nearly 300 meetings with constituents and nearly 200 visits all across our district including schools, non-profit organizations and small businesses. Keep up to date by following my on Facebook, Twitter and visit “Here’s Lloyd” – a diary of all my visits across PA-11.  If you’d like to invite me to your school, business or community organization, please contact me at: Request a meeting.                                          Follow Me On Social Media           Thank you for subscribing to my newsletter! You can stay up-to-date on what I'm doing in Washington and Pennsylvania by following me on Twitter and Facebook. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }        News from Representative Speier Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email                        February 16, 2020 This past week, history was made in the U.S. House of Representatives with a bipartisan vote to pass my resolution to remove the deadline from the preamble of the Equal Rights Amendment. As I said on the House floor, I am an equal to every one of my male colleagues in Congress until I walk out the door and down the steps of the Capitol. Then I am relegated to second-class status because women are not recognized in the Constitution as fully equal to men under the law. Thursday’s vote on H.J.Res.79, my resolution to facilitate ratification of the ERA, was a vote for equality, the American dream, and that more perfect union. I am proud of House Democrats, and five of our Republican colleagues, who joined me in championing the fight for women’s rights and greater equality. House Democrats also continued our work to protect our environment and natural spaces with a sweeping wilderness protection bill, and we voted to establish the first museum in the United States dedicated to the celebration and recognition of women’s history. We also turned the spotlight on threats to our nation with the Military Personnel Committee hearing that I chaired and that focused on the rise of white supremacy in our military, the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the malign actions of foreign adversaries including Russia and China, and my work to expose and eradicate the corrosive effects of sexual assault on our brave servicemembers – which threatens unit cohesion and military readiness. I was proud to introduce a resolution with Congressman Jim McGovern (D-MA) to establish an international anti-corruption court to address the impact that corruption has on human rights worldwide and the challenge of holding kleptocrats accountable for their crimes, and much more as you will read below. I am looking forward to being home in the 14th District this coming week. Then it’s back to Washington, DC the week of February 24th, and a return of Jackie’s DC Dashboard, so be sure to keep an eye out for the next update.                   As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.           Legislative Highlights Passed My Bill to Facilitate Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment  When Congress passed the ERA in 1972, it attached an arbitrary seven-year ratification deadline to the preamble which was later extended three more years. By 1982, 35 states out of the required 38 states voted to ratify the amendment. In the past three years, grassroots campaigns have successfully secured the final ratification votes in Nevada, Illinois, and most recently, Virginia. Unfortunately, the Department of Justice (DOJ) Office of Legal Counsel recently put out a legal opinion that the current ERA push is dead and that Congress lacks the authority to revive it. The Archivist, who is responsible for certifying amendments to the Constitution once ratified by three-fourths of the states, has decided to follow DOJ’s guidance even though Article V makes clear the Executive has no role in the Constitutional amendment process. Our vote to eliminate the arbitrary deadline brings us closer to placing this important guarantee of women’s equality in our founding document. It is now up to the Senate to follow suit and vote on companion legislation by Senators Murkowski and Cardin, and the Archivist to move forward with certifying the ERA.  Voted for Sweeping Wilderness Bill This week, the House took a major step toward protecting our public lands by voting to designate almost 1.4 million acres of land as wilderness and adding 1,000 river miles to the National Wild and Scenic River Systems. H.R. 2546, the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act, would preserve natural spaces in California, Colorado, and Washington for generations to come by protecting them from logging, mining, drilling, and new construction. It would also improve recreational access for underserved communities, safeguard ancestral homelands and tribal access, and boost local economies. Despite the bipartisan House vote, the Senate Majority Mitch McConnell is likely to relegate this critically-needed bill to his legislative graveyard. President Trump has also threatened to veto this legislation if it reaches his desk. But this fight is far from over. Our public lands are our most important natural heritage and an important tool in the fight against climate change. House Democrats will continue to push for wilderness and environmental protections as Americans across the continue to demand action this election year. Voted to Create a Smithsonian Women’s History Museum On Tuesday, House Democrats passed H.R. 1980, the Smithsonian Women’s History Museum Act. This bipartisan legislation would establish a Smithsonian museum dedicated to women’s history on the National Mall. Currently, we do not have a comprehensive museum in America documenting women’s history. Without it, women’s contributions to the nation are too often forgotten and could be lost as distant and forgotten memories. The stories of women in this country are too integral to our history to push aside. I was proud to vote for this historic legislation and urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly pass it so that we can get to work building this museum!    Where’s Jackie? Chaired MILPERS Hearing on White Supremacists in the Military  There are several warning signs that these efforts have found success. Recent high-profile examples include a Marine attending the 2017 Charlottesville rally, a Coast Guard officer arrested with a cache of weapons, and a West Point graduate espousing hate on social media. It seems that the military is not only not taking this threat seriously enough, it also lacks the tools it needs and has failed to dedicate sufficient resources to fighting this threat. At the hearing, we discussed necessary improvements to the accessions process, how we investigate and punish white supremacist activity in the forces, and how we report and track these individuals after they have been expelled from the military. I look forward to an update from military leadership soon on the progress that they will make in focusing on this issue with the seriousness and commitment that it demands. You can watch the hearing here.  House Armed Services Committee Hearing on Threats Posed by Russia and China This week, I attended the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the Defense Department’s role in our national efforts to address the threats and challenges posed by Russia and China—two formidable countries that do not share our values. The DoD is focused on ensuring that the United States is ready to compete with those countries militarily, but at the hearing we discussed the importance of addressing less traditional acts of aggression, such as propaganda operations, cyber-attacks, and predatory economic practices. Countering these threats will require a comprehensive strategy across our government, executed in partnership with our allies.  Spoke on a Panel about Military Sexual Assault  On Wednesday night, I attended Heroine, a one-woman show about a female soldier performed at the beautiful Kennedy Center. The play, which is based on a real story, describes a woman’s struggle with addiction, depression, and suicide after being raped by soldiers in her unit. I was deeply impressed by how the performance conveyed the horror of military sexual assault and lasting pains with which survivors must wrestle. After the play, I sat on a panel with military justice experts to discuss our ongoing efforts to address this issue. As the Chair of the Military Personnel Subcommittee, I have made eradicating military sexual violence a top priority because our military cannot succeed while battling this scourge within its ranks.     Meetings with Jackie Meeting with Local Veterans Affairs Department Union On Wednesday, I met with leaders of AFGE Local 2110, the union that represents workers at our local VA hospital and clinic. We discussed our ongoing efforts to improve VA locality pay to offset the high cost of living in our area and help the VA recruit and retain staff. The VA representatives also shared the way that the Trump Administration’s anti-union actions have constrained their ability to operate. I remain committed to helping AFGE as it fights for its members to receive a living wage and fair representation.  Met with Northern California Special Olympics Delegation  Met with the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District On Wednesday I met with representatives of the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District (GGBHTD) to discuss opportunities for supporting San Francisco’s infrastructure needs. The District shared their plans for upcoming federal grant opportunities, and I look forward to lending my support to their work. We discussed the District’s concerns around the lack of federal funding to California for critical infrastructure needs, such as seismic retrofitting of the Golden Gate Bridge and expansion of the ferry boat system. I share many of their concerns, especially given President Trump’s vindictive attitude toward California.  The GGBHTD also provided updates on important projects and policies such as drone restrictions over the bridge, construction of the suicide net, and new safety measures for the bridge. The Golden Gate Bridge is an icon of the Bay Area as well as a vital piece of infrastructure for the region. I remain committed to supporting GGBHT and the needs of all Bay Area residents.    Voices of California’s 14th District  Here are some issues raised this week:   99 constituents expressed support for H.R. 230, the Ban Toxic Pesticides Act of 2019. I am a cosponsor of this crucial piece of legislation that would ban the use of the pesticide chlorpyrifos and prohibit any future registration of the pesticide. Please know that I will always fight to protect public health and safety, and ensure that our water, produce, and environment is safe from toxic chemicals. 87 constituents expressed concern with fracking.  Like you, I am deeply concerned about the effect of fracking on water sources. I take regulation of hydraulic fracturing seriously and will fight to protect the health and safety of all Americans. I am also deeply committed to supporting clean technology innovation, including solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, advanced biofuels, and other renewable energy sources 27 constituents expressed support for our public lands. Our landscapes and national parks are treasures that must be preserved for future generations. I am proud to have been named a "Friend of the National Parks," and I am committed to conserving our natural heritage. During the first half of February, I attended President Donald Trump's inspiring State of the Union address, traveled with President Trump for the Opportunity Now Summit, and met with school leaders on education issues. I also had the opportunity to personally award the winner of the Congressional App Challenge. Below you can also find information on this year's Congressional Art Competition.  State of the Union Address In President Donald Trump's State of the Union address, he reaffirmed his commitment to keeping his promises.  South Carolina has seen his kept promises first-hand. At 2.3 percent, South Carolina’s unemployment rate is at a record low. Since President Trump’s election, 122,000 jobs have been created in South Carolina—including 19,000 manufacturing jobs, wages increased 4 percent by an average of $5,000 for families in South Carolina. Read my full statement on the President's State of the Union address here.   Opportunity NOW Summit  I was grateful to travel with President Trump for the launch of Opportunity NOW, a new nationwide campaign to revitalize under-served cities and towns across America.    Opportunity NOW Summit   Meetings with Midlands Technical College and Magnet Schools of America This week I met with the Midlands Technical College Board of Trustees to talk about the importance of technical colleges which teach the skills necessary to succeed in our dynamic workforce.   Meeting with Midlands Technical College  Last week, I was recognized by the Magnet Schools of America (MSA) as a Champion of Magnet School Excellence and to be a steadfast supporter of magnet schools, in South Carolina and nationally.    Meeting with the Magnet Schools of America     Congressional App Challenge Winner Congratulations to Milan Dutta of Lexington for winning the Congressional App Challenge for South Carolina’s Second District with his app, “BioHelper.” The Congressional App Challenge is open to all middle and high school students in South Carolina’s Second District. Every year, the winner from the Second District is featured online and the winning app will be eligible to be displayed in the United States Capitol. Details on the 2020 competition will be announced in October.    Awarding the Congressional App Challenge Winner, Milan Dutta of Lexington    Congressional Art Competition Each year, my colleagues and I in the House of Representatives participate in a nationwide high school arts competition sponsored by the Congressional Institute. The Congressional Art Competition is a way to recognize the talent of young artists here in the Second Congressional District of South Carolina and across the nation. This competition is open to all high school students, and one winner is selected to represent the Second District. The winning artwork will be displayed for one year in the U.S. Capitol along with art from all participating districts around the country. This is truly a spectacular exhibit - one that I encourage all to come and see if you are ever in Washington.     More information on how to enter and competition guidelines can be found here.   Sincerely, Member Of Congress                     Washington, DC Office1436 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515phone: (202) 225-2452fax: (202) 225-2455   The Midlands Office1700 Sunset Blvd (US 378), Suite 1West Columbia, SC 29169phone: (803) 939-0041fax: (803) 939-0078   Aiken/Barnwell Office1930 University Parkway, Suite 1600Aiken, SC 29801phone: (803) 642-6416fax: (803) 642-6418                     Unsubscribe | Privacy   Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email

February 14, 2020 Congressman Lipinski Hosts Climate Change Panel at Lewis University Featuring Tom Skilling and Other Climate Experts Rep. Lipinski meets with meteorologist Tom Skilling before the climate panel at Lewis University on February 1st.? ? Watch the panel discussion here  Congressman Lipinski hosted a panel of climate change experts speaking before a sold-out audience at Lewis University on February 1st. The panel, moderated by Rep. Lipinski, featured award-winning WGN-TV Chief Meteorologist Tom Skilling and four other experts speaking about the short and long-term consequences of climate change and potential solutions. Congressman Lipinski has been leading on climate issues since he was first elected to Congress in 2005. The first two bills he introduced that went on to become laws championed innovative solutions to climate change. In 2009, he also helped to introduce the first bipartisan bill to institute a fee on carbon emissions to fight climate change. More recently, the Congressman introduced the bipartisan Raise Wages, Cut Carbon Act, which establishes a fee on greenhouse gas emissions and returns all the revenue generated by cutting payroll taxes, increasing Social Security benefits, and increasing funding for weatherization programs and low-income home energy assistance. The Lewis University panel provided the Congressman with added insight and an opportunity for community feedback. Other panelists at the forum included Doug Sisterson, retired Argonne National Laboratory research meteorologist; Dr. Don Wuebbles, the Harry E. Preble Professor of Atmospheric Science at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign; Dr. Laura Franklin, Dean of Lewis University?s College of Humanities, Fine Arts, and Communications; and Dr. Seth Darling, Director of the Center for Molecular Engineering and Senior Scientist at Argonne National Laboratory. All five panelists spoke directly about the science behind climate change and the need to act. ?I learned so much from the expert panelists on this forum,? Congressman Lipinski said. ?I left with a great sense of optimism after seeing the number of young people who were taking an active interest in climate change.? Congressman Lipinski Helps House Pass Legislation Supporting Unions? Right to Organize Rep. Lipinski speaks about his support for the PRO Act on the floor of the House of Representatives on February 6th. Watch the Congressman?s floor speech here  Congressman Lipinski last week stood up for the rights of union workers by voting forH.R. 2474 , the Protecting the Right to Organize (PRO) Act. The PRO Act guarantees protections against harassment and retribution for workers who attempt to form or join a union. The legislation would ensure that union members in the Third District of Illinois are permitted to stand together in pursuit of higher wages, better benefits, and safer working conditions. The bipartisan effort is designed to offer a comprehensive solution to the problems faced by workers in exercising their right to organize, including ensuring access to fair union elections and preserving collective bargaining agreements. Congressman Lipinski spoke on the House floor in support of the legislation. ?I am a proud supporter of the hardworking men and women of our nation. And no one does more for American workers than organized labor,? said Congressman Lipinski. ?Workers standing together and bargaining collectively have been instrumental in building our Country and our middle class for more than a century. Unions helped bring tens of millions of good paying jobs to Americans by working for fair and safe workplaces and better wages and benefits. In Chicagoland, we are fortunate to have many labor unions fighting every day to improve the lives of workers and their families. Across my district, thousands display a lawn sign created by the Chicago Federation of Labor that reads Proud Union Home, but sadly, some are now trying to hinder collective bargaining and undermine the National Labor Relations Act just at a time where workers need greater protection. I voted to pass the PRO Act because I support American workers and I support American prosperity.? Chairman Lipinski Invites Chicago Alderman Matt O?Shea to Testify at Rail Subcommittee Hearing on Blocked Crossings, Noise, and Safety Concerns Chairman Lipinski stands with Alderman O?Shea following the Feb. 5th hearing of the House Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials.? Watch the full hearing online here  Chairman Lipinski was pleased to welcome 19th Ward Chicago Alderman Matt O?Shea to Capitol Hill last week to testify about blocked rail grade crossings during a hearing of the Congressman?s Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials. Blocked rail crossings at roadways pose several noise and safety concerns for communities in the Third Congressional District, including impeding the flow of traffic and preventing emergency responders from reaching individuals in life-or-death situations. Both Chairman Lipinski and Alderman O?Shea have played an active role in addressing the problem of blocked crossings for several years. Chairman Lipinski has made the issue a priority for his office and for the Subcommittee in the current session of Congress. ?I am committed to exploring innovative solutions that will improve safety and end the gridlock caused by idling or broken-down trains in the Chicago area and around the country,? said Chairman Lipinski. ?This hearing will provide much-needed answers to help us craft laws that will protect our constituents and put an end to practices that hinder their ability to get to work, reach loved ones, and perform the other essential tasks of daily life. Alderman O?Shea?s testimony will give voice to the concerns of area residents, and I am pleased to welcome him to Capitol Hill for the hearing.? Rep. Lipinski Attends Ribbon Cutting for New Warming Shelters at Metra's Summit Station ? Congressman Lipinski joins Metra representatives and community leaders at a ribbon cutting ceremony for a new warming shelter at Metra?s Summit Station. As Chair of the Subcommittee on Railroads, Pipelines, and Hazardous Materials, Congressman Lipinski works to secure federal funds for the Heritage Corridor line and other rail services around the region. Rep. Lipinski Votes for the Great Lakes Restoration Act Congressman Lipinski tours the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal that runs through the Third Congressional District. ? Click here to read Rep. Lipinski's statement in support of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative  The Great Lakes provide drinking water to more than 30 million people, support more than 30,000 jobs, and are home to more than 3,500 plant and animal species. The Great Lakes are essential to life in our region and our nation, but they also face significant threats from algal blooms, pollution, and invasive species. Last week, Congressman Lipinski joined a bipartisan coalition of lawmakers to support The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (H.R. 4031 ), which helps to protect vital resources and ensure the continued health of the Great Lakes. The Congressman served as a co-sponsor of the legislation and worked to inform other members about the benefits of the Initiative. ?Constituents of the Third District regularly reach out to me to emphasize the importance of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. Those constituents recognize how important the Great Lakes are to our region, and I could not agree more,? said Congressman Lipinski. ?The Great Lakes Restoration Initiative provides vital protections for our drinking water, environment, and local economy. I am proud to stand with members on both sides of the aisle in leading the fight for this initiative.?      Unsubscribe  ? ? ? This legislation addresses growing student loan debt by making the student loan interest tax deduction work better for married couples. Current law penalizes married couples by only allowing them to take one deduction—even if both spouses qualify. This bill would stop this unfair tax on student loans against married couples while also helping individuals with their student loan debt burden. For decades, hardworking Americans have been saddled with student loan debt which has delayed their dreams of achieving financial stability. I am proud to lead this effort to maximize the student loan interest tax deduction that married couples can claim each tax year. This allows married couples to put more towards paying off their student loans, incur less interest, put more food on the table, or save a little more for a down payment on a home. This unfair marriage penalty came to my attention after Claudia McHale, a constituent from Garden City, discussed with me the situation of her niece and her husband. Both of them paid towards reducing their student loan yet were only able to claim a $2,500 deduction between the two of them, the same maximum amount a single individual can claim every tax year. As Claudia said, “it is ridiculous that the federal government punishes taxpayers with student loan balances just because they get married.”                                                   __________  On Tuesday, I received the True Blue Award from the Family Research Council. This recognition is awarded to Members of Congress with a proven record of defending the right to life, religious freedoms, and family values.   It is truly an honor to represent Missouri's 4th congressional district as we fight for our foundational values.  Legislative Update On Thursday, Democrat leadership in the House attempted resurrect the 1972 Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) through Congress.  I commend the women who have gone before us, to celebrate the achievements women have made, and to reaffirm the fact that we are already equal in the eyes of God and in law. Women make up 51% of the population, comprise over half of college students, make up most of today’s medical and law school students, and own the majority of new businesses. Little girls can be whatever they want to be whether that be an astronaut, a doctor, a full-time mom working at home, or a Member of Congress.  In addition, federal law and court precedent uphold our rights. That is something to applaud and I do.  However, today’s legislation is problematic on several fronts. First, the resolution is unconstitutional. The time limit to pass the ERA expired decades ago. Congress can’t go back and remove a deadline from a previous constitutional amendment initiative. The Supreme Court has recognized that the 1972 ERA expired, and the Department of Justice issued a ruling saying, “Congress may not revive a proposed amendment after a deadline for its ratification has expired.” Pretending we can remove the time limits for passage is both futile and deceptive. Secondly, if the time limit COULD be extended, the ERA would not bring women any more rights than they currently have but it would entrench the legality of abortion. We know this from court precedent and by listening to those who have the most to gain from constitutionally protecting abortion on demand.  In 1998, the New Mexico Supreme Court ruled that the Equal Rights Amendment in their state constitution requires state-funding of abortions. Federal courts are likely to do the same. Perhaps this is why every major pro-abortion organization is endorsing passage of the ERA.  NARAL Pro-Choice America says: “With its ratification, the ERA would reinforce the constitutional right to abortion….” National Organization for Women: “An ERA—properly interpreted—could negate the hundreds of laws that have been passed restricting access to abortion care.…” But that’s not the only concern with passing this resolution. Besides being unconstitutional and shredding state and federal pro-life protections, the ERA would also erase decades of progress which have provided opportunities for women, advanced women’s progress through federal programs, and secured necessary protections for women and girls. How? By incorporating gender identity in the definition of ‘sex’, jeopardizing private spaces for women, girls’ sports programs, and women’s educational institutions.  By banning distinctions between men and women, the ERA also endangers laws, programs and funding designed to benefit women. The ERA provides a pathway for legal challenges to welfare programs, grants for battered women’s shelters, efforts to bolster women participating in STEM programs. These outcomes of the ERA are anything but pro-woman. I urge my colleagues to vote ‘No’ on today’s resolution and uphold the Constitution, promote life, and protect women’s rights that have been so hard-fought gained.  District Update I am so pleased to tell you about an honor recently won by Columbia Public Schools. Project Tomorrow is a national education nonprofit dedicated to ensuring that today’s students are well prepared to be tomorrow’s innovators, leaders, and engaged citizens of the world. Project Tomorrow is recognizing Columbia Public Schools with its annual Speak Up District of Honor award, an honor given to school districts for leadership and commitment to listening to the voices and views of students, parents, and educators.    I believe it is through these valuable exchanges that better learning experiences are created for students from kindergarten through the 12th grade. Congratulations to Columbia Public Schools for earning this distinction and for its dedication to improving and enhancing the educational experience for its students.  Constituent Update I want to share with you that our office has joined forces with the Library of Congress to help preserve, forever, the stories of our veterans.   The Veterans History Project began as an effort to collect the accounts of America’s World War II heroes, many of whom are passing away without their stories being saved for posterity. It has since expanded to veterans of all military encounters with the goal of ensuring their personal memories are recorded and made available for future generations. If you are a veteran or if you know a veteran who would like to share your experiences as part of the Veterans History Project, contact Steve Walsh in our Columbia office at 573-442-9311. Every time I step on the House floor, I’m focused on legislation that will help our district - whether that’s lowering out of pocket health care costs or making sure every student gets a quality education. No matter what is happening in Washington, I won’t lose sight of the issues we face back home.  I was especially lucky to introduce Kathy Zeman to the House Agriculture Committee earlier this week. Kathy farms in Rice County and she came to Washington to testify in support of the Local Agricultural Markets Program which promotes farmers’ markets around the country.         Expanding Higher Ed Opportunities  On Tuesday, I spoke with Minnesota State about how we can expand higher ed opportunities for our students. If education isn’t affordable, it’s not accessible.         Improving Rural Health CareRight now, there are insufficient health care resources in our rural communities. Wednesday, I met with folks from the Minnesota Department of Health to talk about the unique healthcare challenges facing rural patients and providers.       Advocating for Minnesota River Funding This week, I sat down with the Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, and the Waterways Council to discuss the importance of the Minnesota River Dredging project in keeping the river fully operational. The river transports about 4 million tons annually, worth more than $362 Million in economic value.         Pushing for Ratification of the ERA: Equal rights for women should not have a deadline. In fact, it’s long past time. That’s why I voted to remove the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment on Thursday.  Protecting Medicare, Medicaid, and Social SecurityThe President’s budget proposes cuts to Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. I’ll never stand for that. Watch my video about these cuts here.   Supporting the Special OlympicsThis week was Special Olympics Hill Day! It was great meeting with our Minnesota delegation about empowering folks with different abilities.       Meeting Rescue PuppiesThursday, I stopped by the ASPCA Paws for Love pet adoption event to give out some belly rubs.         Funding Recreational TrailsThis week, I introduced the Recreational Trails Full Funding Act of 2020 with Rep. Welch to make sure folks have quality trails to enjoy Minnesota’s four seasons for hiking, cross country skiing and taking their ATV’s out. Not only will this bill invest in these opportunities right now, but it also makes sure future generations of Minnesotans and visitors can experience the beauty of the Minnesota River Valley and our well-traveled trails from Zumbrota to Cottage Grove.   Upcoming Event:Excited to announce my February town hall! I hope you can join me on Feb. 19th in Savage          Sincerely,   Angie CraigMember of Congress           Washington, DC Office 1523 Longworth House Office Building Washington, DC Phone: (202) 225-2271   Burnsville, MN Office 12940 Harriet Avenue South Suite 238 Burnsville, MN Phone: (651) 846-2120         Open in browser window        Open plain text version    Unsubscribe

It was a very eventful week and I'm excited to tell you about what we accomplished. Here are some highlights:   I was the Grand Marshall for the Ninth Annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade I toured the Indian River Lagoon to see living shorelines and learn more about preserving our environment I attended the signing of the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act by President Trump at the White House I spoke on the House floor in recognition of Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune and her contributions to our community and country  CELEBRATING OUR RACING HISTORY: This weekend I had the honor of serving as the Grand Marshall of this year’s Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade! Since the 1920s, Daytona Beach has been the home of NASCAR, with drivers setting records racing down our beach to the famous North Turn and A1A. This race is an important part of our community’s history and it’s always one of my favorite events every year!    Serving as Grand Marshall at the 9th annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade  CONSERVING OUR SHORELINE: Our beautiful and natural shorelines can co-exist with development when done correctly. Living shorelines and mangroves are important for our communities because they are the best natural barriers against storm surges. Estuaries and mangroves are also important to commercial fisherman. Around 80 percent of them rely on estuaries and mangroves for spawning. I enjoyed touring our local living shorelines to learn more about how conservancies bring free market, volunteering and community based solutions to our community. It's important we maintain our living shorelines to help keep Florida resilient.     Views of our Indian River Lagoon living shoreline  SUPPORTING OUR VETERANS: This week, I went to the White House to see President Trump sign another bill supporting our veterans into law — and this time, it was a bill I co-sponsored! The Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act supports our veterans, helping them find opportunities for jobs in STEM fields when they return to civilian life. I was glad to work on this bill with two fellow Florida congressmen, Senator Marco Rubio and Congressman Neal Dunn, and I was proud to be there as the President signed it into law!    President Trump signing the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act into law RECOGNIZING SERVANT LEADERSHIP: I can't think of anyone better to highlight great servant leadership in our community and our country this Black History Month than our district's very own Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune. Bethune founded and was President of the all African-American girls school in Daytona Beach, which later became Bethune–Cookman University. Bethune selflessly dedicated herself to fighting for the equality and civil rights of all Americans through education and because of her, Florida and America are a better place.  Click below to watch me honor Dr. Bethune on the House floor:    Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service.  In Service,    Michael Waltz                Washington, DC 216 Cannon House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2706 Deland Office 120 South Florida Ave.Suite 324Deland, FL 32720Phone: (386) 279-0707 Palm Coast Office 31 Lupi CourtSuite 130Palm Coast, FL 32137Phone: (386)-302-0442 Port Orange Office Port Orange City Hall1000 City Center Circle2nd FloorPort Orange, FL 32129Phone: (386) 238-9711          Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version

It is important to remember that Congress holds the power of the purse. The President's budget is merely a reflection of his priorities and a suggestion to the House and Senate. His proposal demonstrates his commitment to decreasing our national debt and balancing our federal budget, and we can use his proposal to guide our discussions in Congress. I am proud to serve on the powerful Appropriations Committee, which sets the funding levels for discretionary spending, and we have a lot of work to do. We have already started hosting Appropriations Subcommittee hearings to discuss funding for different departments and offices of the federal government. One place where I believe the President's budget proposal fell short was at Hanford. Since I came to Congress, every Administration has proposed cuts to the Hanford cleanup, and I have worked across the aisle to restore funding. Federal dollars are critical to ensuring the men and women of the Hanford workforce are able to safely and efficiently clean up the millions of gallons of nuclear waste at the Hanford Site, keep our groundwater and the Columbia River safe from contamination, and fulfill the federal government's promise to the Tri-Cities community.     The Columbian: "In Our View: Nuclear waste requires innovative solutions"  President Trump's proposal also did not include funding for the licensing of Yucca Mountain, which is a change from his previous position. It is the law of the land: Yucca Mountain is the nation's sole permanent repository for nuclear waste. With 56 gallons of nuclear waste at the Hanford Site alone, no district in the United States is more dependent on Yucca Mountain than Washington's 4th. I have met personally with the President to urge him to reconsider his change in position.  As we continue through the Appropriations process, I will work to represent Central Washington's priorities and ensure the federal government fulfills its moral and legal obligation to clean up the Hanford Site.   Healthy Forests Prevent Wildfires   In Central Washington, we understand how important active land management is for wildfire prevention. I am proud to support commonsense land management practices and policies that both protect our national forests and communities from wildfires but also protect the environment. My friend, Rep. Westerman, recently introduced the Trillion Trees Act that would plant 1 trillion trees by 2050 and incentivize the use of wood products as carbon sequestration devices. This week, I visited with U.S. Forest Service Chief Vicki Christiansen and attended a Summit on Active Forest Management and Wildfire Suppression, hosted by the Western Caucus, to discuss Rep. Westerman's proposal and several ways we can promote healthy forests and sustain our public lands. Native Communities Have Had Enough   Patricia Whitefoot has been an incredible advocate for Native women and a critical ally for me as we work in Congress to address the crisis of missing and murdered indigenous women. She joined me in the nation's Capitol to discuss our legislative efforts like Savanna's Act that - for too long - have been stalled in the Judiciary Committee. I have met with tribal leaders across the Pacific Northwest to hear how this crisis is affecting our communities. One thing is clear: Native communities have had enough. We cannot continue to drag our feet while the loved ones of these women wait for answers.  Calling All High School Artists: Congressional Art Competition   The 2020 Central Washington Congressional Art Competition is now OPEN! This competition is an opportunity for students in Central Washington to tell a story and express themselves through art. Year after year, I am impressed by the talent and creativity of these young people. I look forward to seeing the new submissions!  The Art Competition is open to all high school students in Washington's 4th Congressional District. The winner's artwork will hang in the U.S. Capitol for one year, and the winning artist will receive two plane tickets to Washington D.C. Find more details, rules, and regulations on my website.   To stay current on the work I am doing around the District and in Washington D.C., I encourage you to follow me  on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and to read updates on my website.  It is an honor and a privilege to represent you in Congress.  Sincerely,  Dan Newhouse Member of Congress          NEXT WEEK: Senior Symposium Thursday, February 20: Yakima Harman Senior Center 101 North 65th Avenue 9:00AM - 12:00PM   All seniors in Central Washington are invited to join the Senior Symposium in Yakima.   Find event details here.  UPCOMING MOBILE OFFICE HOURS My staff hosts monthly Mobile Office Hours across Central Washington. These Hours are open to all constituents, no appointment necessary.  Monday, February 24: Connell Connell City Hall104 East Adams Street11:00AM - 1:00PM Wednesday, February 26: East Wenatchee Pangborn Airport Cafe1 Panborn Drive11:00AM - 1:00PM  Thursday, March 12: Omak Omak City Hall2 North Ash Street10:00AM - 12:00PM  Monday, March 16: Othello Othello City Hall500 East Main Street10:00AM - 12:00PM  Monday, March 23: Connell Connell City Hall104 East Adams Street11:00AM - 1:00PM   Thursday, March 26: East Wenatchee Pangborn Airport Cafe1 Pangborn Drive11:00AM - 1:00PM  Mobile Office Hours are listed on my website for the month ahead.   Constituents are always welcome to visit my permanent offices in Yakima and Richland. Yakima AveSuite #1000Yakima, WA 98901Phone: (509) 452-3243Fax: (509) 452-3438   Tri-Cities Office 3100 George Washington Way Suite #130Richland, WA 99354Phone: (509) 713-7374Fax: (509) 713-7377   North District: Okanogan and Douglas Counties 705 Omache DriveSuite E #413Omak, WA 98841Phone: (509) 433-7760          Unsubscribe | Privacy     Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window    Click here to open a plain text version of this email           /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }         News from Representative Sires                                         Last week in Washington, the House passed critical reforms for the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) and expanded essential labor rights. I met with leaders on education and labor policy to inform my legislative work and attended hearings with my colleagues on the House Foreign Affairs Committee.   Legislation Meetings  Foreign Affairs  Legislation  Last Tuesday, the House considered a bill that I cosponsored, H.R. 2382, the USPS Fairness Act, introduced by Rep. Peter DeFazio (D-OR). In 2006, the United States Postal Service was required to be the only government agency to pre-fund health care for all employees present and future. In the changing landscape of distribution in the following 14 years, I believe, along with many of my colleagues, that this is an unsustainable burden on of our nation’s most important public services. I voted in favor of H.R. 2382, which would repeal the 2006 mandate and passed on a bipartisan vote of 309-106.  Last Thursday, I voted in favor of H. Res.826, a bill expressing disapproval of the Administration’s Medicaid block grant proposal, introduced by Rep. Marc Veasey (D-TX). It is critical to protect Medicaid recipients against any efforts to undermine or reduce coverage, especially in the face of rising health care and prescription drug costs. H.Res.826 passed by a vote 223-190. Later that day, I also voted for another bill that I cosponsored, H.R. 2474, the Protecting the Right to Organize Act of 2019, introduced by Rep. Bobby Scott (D-VA). As inequality in our economy spikes, the rights of workers to organize and protect themselves must be guarded at all costs. H.R. 2474 protects the right to strike, the right to act in solidarity with workers at other companies, the right to pursue justice through class action, and other fundamental rights.  This bill also strengthens the ability of workers to negotiate for higher wages, better benefits, and secure first contract agreements. H.R. 2474 passed by a vote of 224-194.  Crucially, the House also passed H.R. 5687, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Disaster Relief and Puerto Rico Disaster Tax Relief Act, introduced by Rep. Nita Lowey (D-NY). This package provides $4.67 billion in emergency supplemental aid for Puerto Rico following a series of intense earthquakes in recent months. I voted in favor of this package and will continue working with my colleagues to help Puerto Rico rebuild.  H.R. 5687 passed by a vote of 237-161. All of the bills passed this week have been sent to the Senate for consideration. Meetings  Last Wednesday, I met with representatives of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers. We discussed my support for labor unions and the work Congress is currently undertaking to progress labor rights across the country. The following day, I met with the National Education Association. Speaking with NEA Director Donna Mirabelli and New Jersey Director Anita Kober, we went over legislative priorities for protecting our public schools and expanding funding to ensure the success of students. Afterwards, I spoke at “Dominicans on the Hill” day, an event hosted by my friend Rep. Adriano Espaillat (D-NY). I am thrilled every year to meet with the constituents who travel to Washington and am proud to be a longtime supporter of the Dominican community.  Foreign Affairs   I attended a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing on Wednesday focused on the challenges facing women in global health. As Chairman of the Western Hemisphere Subcommittee, I was proud to bring the knowledge my Subcommittee colleagues and I have fostered on women’s health issues to the full Committee hearing. When I visited the Venezuela-Colombia border, I spoke directly with Venezuelan women about their concerns for the health and safety of them and their children. Sheba Crocker, Vice President for Humanitarian Policy and Practice at the relief agency CARE, emphasized how the stories I heard firsthand represent the prevalence of gender-based violence, stemming in part from the Venezuela crisis. Congress must always look to lift up marginalized voices in the creation of our foreign policy and work to overcome challenges women face in global health.   As Latvia will celebrate the 30th anniversary of independence from the Soviet Union later this year, I met with Rihards Kols, Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee for the Latvian Saeima, and Reinis Znotins, Chairman of the IT and Innovative Entrepreneurship Subcommittee. I emphasized my commitment to combating Russian aggression and we discussed how a Belarus travel ban could make the country more susceptible to Russian influence. On Thursday, I sat down with Metin Hakverdi, a member of the German Bundestag, to express our mutual support for a strong U.S.- German relationship. Also last Thursday, I met with Juan Guaidó, Venezuela’s Interim President, along with Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other House colleagues. Nearly 5 million Venezuelans have been forced to flee their homes due to a humanitarian crisis caused by Nicolás Maduro. I spoke with President Guaidó about how to bolster our international aid response and promote democratic elections in Venezuela. Additionally, I voiced my support for granting Temporary Protected Status (TPS) to protect Venezuelans already here in the U.S. Last Friday, I met with Taiwan’s Vice President Elect, Lai Ching-te, along with some of my colleagues on the House Foreign Affairs Committee. We discussed Taiwan’s recent election, Taiwan’s response to the coronavirus, and the U.S-Taiwan partnership.  Thank you for reading the Washington Review. Again, hearing from my constituents enables me to be a better representative of the 8th District. For regular updates, you may stay in touch by leaving comments on my Facebook, Twitter, and website.        Sincerely,Albio SiresMember of Congress                  Washington, DC Office 2342 Rayburn HOB Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-7919 Jersey City Office 257 Cornelison Ave. Suite 4408 Jersey City, NJ 07302 Phone: 201-309-0301 Elizabeth Office 800 Anna Street Elizabeth, NJ 07201 Phone: 908-820-0692 West New York Office 5500 Palisade Avenue, Suite A West New York, NJ 07093 Phone: 201-558-0800           Unsubscribe | Privacy  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
