name: Congressman Greg Murphy M.D.
subject: From Congressman Murphy's Desk
body: Latest News Impeachment is finally over After more than four long, divisive and counter-productive months, impeachment is finally over and the president has been rightfully acquittedthe actions of the president did not warrant the charges. Congress has been stuck at a standstill for too long. Having been sworn into Congress only a week prior to the beginning of the impeachment inquiry, I am thankful this storm has passed and I can finally begin the legislative work eastern North Carolinians elected me to do. Congress could and should have been working on issues like healthcare, prescription drugs, border security and more instead of this tiresome and illegitimate impeachment. Hopefully, we can finally get back to tending to the business of the people. Unfortunately, I doubt that will be the case after the petty and partisan theatrics displayed by Speaker Pelosi at the State of the Union address. Bipartisan efforts that would benefit the American people will likely be forgone due to the Speakers disdain for the president and her fear of giving him legislative victories. America deserves better. What's going on with coronavirus? As a physician and member of Congress, I wanted to give you all an update on the status of the coronavirus and how the United States is working to combat its spread. Watch the video below to learn more. Surprise billing There is bipartisan agreement that surprise billing is a major problem for patients and families across America. It desperately needs to be addressed. While Im glad we discussed the best path forward to alleviate the problems of surprise billing during a markup of H.R. 5800 in the House Committee on Education and Labor this week, this legislation is not the right solution to this problem. Even though I couldn't support H.R. 5800 in its entirety, I was glad to improve it with two amendments that were adopted unanimously. As a physician, I'll continue to utilize my expertise on these issues to lower the cost of healthcare and increase patient access to provide Americans with the greatest treatments possible. Watch my opening statement below: Veterans HOPE Act Last week, I was proud to introduce the Veterans HOPE Act to prevent opioid overdose deaths among veterans. Between 2010 and 2016, deaths due to opioid overdose rose by 65% among veterans. During those same years, veteran deaths caused by heroin and synthetic opioids like fentanyl increased by roughly five-fold. Meanwhile, the rate of prescription opioid receipts within three months before death declined by more than 25%, suggesting that opioid overdoses are likely stemming from hard or synthetic drugs, without knowledge of the initial prescriber. To combat this issue, the Veterans HOPE Act would direct the Secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs to further investigate deaths caused by heroin and synthetic opioids. Upon conclusion of the study, the Secretary would report findings to the public and Congress and suggest veteran overdose prevention efforts to save lives. As a member of the North Carolina State Assembly, authoring the main legislative actions to combat the opioid crisis in North Carolina was one of my proudest achievements. Now as the U.S. Representative of a Congressional District with the fifth most veterans in America, the Veterans HOPE Act is especially important research to me. The data speaks for itselfveteran deaths caused by non-prescribed opioids like heroin and fentanyl have skyrocketed. But our veterans are more than a statistic. They are sons and daughters, husbands and wives, and fathers and mothers who have selflessly sacrificed so much for our great nation. It is our duty to do all we can to protect them from the dangers of opioid addiction. You can read the bill here. District Highlights George Henry White Commemorative Stamp Act Honored to introduce legislation this week alongside several of my North Carolina colleagues to honor George Henry White of New Bern, a Republican politican and the last black member of Congress during Reconstruction. George Henry White courageously stood up to racial injustice in a hostile time period for African Americans, especially in the South. The cause of Civil Rights in this country was only advanced because of strong and brave leaders like him. It was only fitting that we honor such a historic African American figure during Black History Month. You can read more about his life and legacy here. Walter B. Jones, Jr. Post Office Almost one year after Congressman Walter B. Jones, Jr.'s passing, Im pleased that a bill I introduced in his honor advanced through the House of Representatives. This measure would designate a post office in his hometown of Farmville, the "Walter B. Jones, Jr. Post Office." It was altogether fitting that my first piece of legislation as a member of Congress be a tribute to my predecessor, friend and mentor. Walter cared deeply for the people of eastern North Carolina, especially the Marines who serve at Camp Lejeune, Cherry Point and New River. He epitomized what a public servant stood forhis constituents. I greatly appreciate my colleagues in the North Carolina delegation for unanimously supporting this bill, and I hope the Senate and President Trump will swiftly act to make this bill a law. You can watch my remarks from the House floor in support of the bill below: Christina Koch Returns to Earth Congratulations to Christina Koch for completing her 328 day mission in space! Welcome back to planet Earth! Christina grew up in Jacksonville and attended NC State. Her time aboard the International Space Station set the record for the longest single continuous spaceflight by a female. Such a tremendous accomplishment for North Carolina, the United States of America and all of humanity. Welcome home, Christina! You can read more about her record-breaking flight here. District Work Even though I've been in our nation's capital for the past two weeks, I've met with numerous people and organizations from North Carolina, many of whom are from the Third District. Scroll through the photos below to see some of the people I met. Had a productive discussion about how Congress can impact state and local narcotic issues with Sgt. Kevin Black, Lt. Daniel Duckworth, Sgt. Mike Dawson, Special Agent Joe Barringer and Sgt. Jason Chappell. Enjoyed talking with representatives from the Pulp and Paperworkers' Resource Council. Forestry is such a vital part of the economy in eastern North Carolina. These gentlemen work at International Paper's facility in New Bern. I learned a great deal about this wonderful renewable resource. It was an honor meeting UNC Chapel Hill's Athletic Director, Bubba Cunningham, and other senior athletic department officials. We talked about college athletics and issues relating to student-athlete compensation that are affecting the NCAA. Met with Tom Gentile, President and CEO of Spirit AeroSystems to discuss their business and presence in North Carolina. Such an honor to attend the North Carolina Opportunity Now Summit with President Trump and several of my colleagues from the North Carolina Congressional delegation. Cutting taxes and red tape has helped create jobs and raise wages across every demographic. We have helped stressed areas of our country by raising people out of poverty with jobs and pride. So much better than creating more government dependency. I will continue to support this administration and its pro-growth policies while serving the great people of eastern North Carolina. It was great meeting with Winston Salem Special Olympics athlete, Jennifer Wardlow, and President and CEO of Special Olympics North Carolina, Keith Fishburne. The Special Olympics is a truly fantastic organization. Honored to meet with the Secretary of Agriculture, Sonny Perdue, with several of my colleagues from the North Carolina delegation. Agriculture is extremely important in eastern North Carolina, and recent trade victories like USMCA and the Phase One trade agreement with China are big wins for American farmers. As a physician, I always enjoy discussing how we can improve America's healthcare system. Had a productive discussion with representatives from National Rural Health. Access, equity and quality of healthcare are especially important issues in places like eastern North Carolina. Thanks for reading! Thank you for signing up to receive my newsletter. I would greatly appreciate it if you could forward this to your family and friends so they can receive periodic updates about what's happening in our nation's capital and eastern North Carolina. It's important to me as a U.S. Representative to keep constituents up to date about my position on the issues in DC, achievements made by people from the district and more. If you are not subscribed already, you can click on the link here. If I can ever be of assistance, or you would just simply like to voice your opinion, please contact my office at (202) 225-3415 or visit my website.

name: Senator Cory Gardner
subject: A message from Senator Cory Gardner
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     p { margin-bottom:1em; }                            Home  Press Releases                Dear Friend,  $28 Million Secured to Provide Clean Drinking Water for 50,000 Coloradans   Click here or the photo above to watch Senator Gardner’s remarks.  I am proud to announce that I have secured significant funding to start construction on the Arkansas Valley Conduit, which will provide clean drinking water for 50,000 Coloradans in 40 communities. This is the first time funding has been secured since Congress authorized the project and President Kennedy promised completion nearly six decades ago. The communities of the Lower Arkansas Valley deserve clean drinking water, which the Arkansas Valley Conduit will supply for generations to come. This is the first time robust federal funding of $28 million has been dedicated to the project which will help finish final design, pre-construction costs, and begin construction to get to the first community in need. In Pueblo last week I celebrated the good news with members of the Southeastern Colorado Water Conservancy District and discussed the next steps on the project. Read more from the Pueblo Chieftain.  Learn More About My Guest to the State of the Union Address   Click here or the picture above to watch remarks from Senator Gardner and his State of the Union guest Kristen Christy on destigmatizing mental health.  I’m honored that Kristen Christy, the 2018 Air Force Spouse of the Year, attended the State of the Union Address as my guest. Kristen has experienced heartbreaking loss that no family should ever have to face. Through her strength and commitment to military families, Kristen has become an inspiring suicide prevention advocate and guiding light for the Air Force and entire military community as she helps others transition from post-traumatic stress to post-traumatic growth. Her resilience, courage, and her never-quit attitude exemplify the best of the American spirit, and it’s fitting that someone with her inspirational and moving story was in the room as the president highlighted the progress and opportunities for our great country. Meeting with Fort Carson Officials About Infrastructure Improvements and the Novel Coronavirus  I recently visited Fort Carson and received an update on Gate 19 construction and infrastructure improvement projects both on base and in the community. We also discussed the possibility of evacuees from the novel coronavirus outbreak being quarantined at Fort Carson. I appreciate the leadership on base that is organized and ready if needed to assist our nation's response and containment of this virus. I wrote to leaders on the Senate Appropriations Committee requesting that they work with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to ensure robust funding to respond to the novel coronavirus outbreak. As the novel coronavirus continues to spread around the world, HHS, through a number of its agencies, is actively leading critical prevention, containment, and supply chain stability efforts. Congress must serve as a collaborative partner and ensure that there is sufficient funding for both current and potential future efforts to contain this communicable and deadly virus. Meeting with the Fort Collins Chamber of Commerce  I recently had a great discussion with the Fort Collins Chamber of Commerce Legislative Affairs Committee on water policy, transportation and housing issues, and ways we can work together to grow the economy and boost job creation in Colorado. I always enjoy meeting with Coloradans to gain their input on a variety of issues and help bring more of Colorado to Washington.  New Renovations at the Colorado Springs Airport    I had a great visit at the Colorado Springs Airport to discuss renovations and growth, including plans for a new airtanker base and ramp to support firefighting efforts. Year after year, much of the West is forced to deal with horrible wildfires that burn millions of acres. Our firefighters risk everything to protect our communities and it's our duty to make sure they have every possible tool to safely fight wildfires. This new airtanker base will serve as an incredible resource for firefighters in Colorado and surrounding areas. Providing Student Loan Relief for Colorado Students In November, the Department of Education announced it would cancel the loans taken out by students to attend the Art Institute of Colorado between January 20, 2018 – when the school lost its accreditation – and December 31, 2018 – when they shut their doors. Senator Michael Bennet (D-CO) and I urged Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos to extend the school discharge eligibility period because the relief is incomplete and does not relieve students of the debt they took on to attend the school prior to January 20, 2018, which is now worthless. At our urging, the Department of Education agreed to expand student loan forgiveness for those who attended the Art Institute of Colorado at the time the school lost its accreditation, meaning more Colorado students will receive full relief on federal loans still owed, as well as a refund of loans they have already paid.  Supporting Sugar Beet Farmers After Adverse Weather Conditions The past two years have been devastating for Cooperative farmers working in Colorado, Montana, Nebraska, and Wyoming due to significant weather events. In 2018 and 2019, growing regions across these states experienced freezing temperatures in early October before sugar beets are typically harvested. I sent a bipartisan letter with Senator Michael Bennet (D-CO) and a bipartisan group of our colleagues urging U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue to take immediate action in implementing the sugar beet eligibility provisions that were passed in the Fiscal Year 2020 Appropriations bill as part of the Wildfire, Hurricane, and Indemnity Program Plus (WHIP+). This program has been essential for farmers during adverse weather growing seasons, and USDA’s swift action is necessary in order for farmers to obtain operating loans for the 2020 crop.  Meeting Taiwan’s Vice President-Elect Lai Ching-te  I was honored to meet with Taiwan’s Vice President-elect Lai Ching-te recently and reaffirm that the U.S. Congress will continue to advocate on behalf of Taiwan as guided by U.S. law, including the Taiwan Relations Act, the Taiwan Travel Act, and my Asia Reassurance Initiative Act. I also relayed my concerns with the World Health Organization excluding Taiwan as the novel coronavirus spreads around the globe. As China continues its aggressive campaign to delegitimize Taiwan, it’s critically important for the U.S. to reaffirm our support for Taiwan. I have offices in Denver, Durango, Pueblo, Grand Junction, Fort Collins, Greeley, Yuma, and Colorado Springs. Learn more about how we can help here.   Thank you for taking the time to read my weekly update. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                    February 14, 2020               Home About Me Contact Media Center Services                     Passing Bill Increasing the Number of Agricultural Specialists for U.S. Customs and Border Protection  This week, I voted in favor of the Protecting America’s Food and Agriculture Act, legislation I proudly cosponsored. This bill authorizes U.S. Customs and Border Protection to add 240 new U.S. Customs and Border Protection Agriculture Specialists, 20 agriculture canine teams, and additional support staff in the Office of Field Operations each fiscal year. This is expected to continue until the number of specialists sustains the requirements put forward by the Agriculture Resource Allocation Model. It is in the best interest of our national security to ensure that our food supply is sufficiently protected from any outside interference. In my many visits to our Northern Border, I have witnessed firsthand the need for more staffers who are specifically trained in this area. I proudly voted in favor of this legislation to provide adequate resources and staffing at our borders and protect our country’s food and agriculture interests. Read more here,   Urging FDA Action on Dairy Labeling Rules  This week, I sent a letter to the new Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Commissioner Steven Hahn, urging him to take action to enforce the FDA standards of identity that are already in place for dairy products. The FDA has formal rules surrounding the definition of labeling genuine dairy products and alternatives that they have chosen not to enforce for several years. I am also cosponsor of the Dairy PRIDE Act, a House bill that would amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prohibit the sale of any food that uses the market name of a dairy product but does not come from an animal, and does not contain milk as a primary ingredient. This letter to the FDA is the next step in urging them to act on dairy labeling issues. For far too long, the FDA has failed to combat the misuse of dairy terms on non-dairy products. Not only does this cause confusion among consumers, but it also puts our North Country dairy farmers at a disadvantage in the grocery store. Real dairy products come from real cows, and they should be the only products labeled as “milk”. I will continue to be an outspoken advocate and urge FDA to enforce existing law. Read more here.   Dropping the Puck in Glens Falls to Stick It to Cancer and Helping Kids Learn to Skate   This past weekend, I had the pleasure of attending the community "Try Hockey for Free" event in Glens Falls, where I helped introduce many young constituents to the sport of hockey. This great event was hosted by the New York Rangers hockey team.  I also had the opportunity to participate in the puck drop at the Adirondack Thunder game. NY-21 is hockey country, and it is amazing to see our youth carry on the tradition!  Meeting with Constituents and Groups Important to the North Country    I met with the Agriculture Retailers Association to discuss their priorities, including agriculture labor reform, infrastructure, rural broadband, and the importance of training the next generation of our workforce.    It was great to meet with constituents and representatives from the Center for Lyme Action to discuss the important work they are doing. In Congress, I work diligently to promote prevention and treatment for Lyme disease. I am a cosponsor of the TICK Act, legislation to establish an office of oversight and coordination for tick-borne diseases. I will continue to support increased funding for research into this disease that affects many of my constituents and many people throughout the country.   I also met with General Joseph M. Martin, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army. We discussed many issues facing Fort Drum, including improvements to childcare facilities and childcare facility worker hiring standards. I look forward to prioritizing the Army's requests for the upcoming National Defense Authorization Act. I am proud to be the number one advocate for Fort Drum in Congress. Cosponsoring the Forest Recovery Act  This week, I cosponsored the bipartisan Forest Recovery Act, legislation that will support timber farmers who have been affected by catastrophic loss events. The bill will help forest landowners recover from natural disasters by eliminating the basis limitation rule and allowing them to deduct up to the fair market value of their devastated trees. This levels the playing field for timber farmers who have been impacted by events like extreme weather and forest fires. Farmers across many sectors continue to be impacted by extreme weather events, and not all of them are protected by crop insurance. This bipartisan bill will help timber producers continue their business, which will have a positive impact on many of our North Country communities who include timber production as part of their economic base. Read more here.  Cosponsoring Bill to Ensure All Active Duty Overseas Military Ballots Are Counted  I also became a cosponsor of the Counting All Military Votes Act, legislation to make Express Mail Labels available to deployed active duty military serving on our embassies, consulates, and/or in diplomatic posts. This will ensure each of their absentee votes will be successfully delivered on time by Express Mail in order to be counted. As the Representative of the 10th Mountain Division, the most deployed unit in the U.S. Army, our district understands that their participation in the electoral process is critical. Our brave men and women serving in active duty overseas assignments deserve a say in our government and elected leaders. Each of their votes must be counted, and this legislation ensures expedited mailing for their absentee ballots. We are forever indebted to those who sacrifice daily while fighting for our freedom and I’m honored to advocate for our great servicemembers in Congress. Read more here.  Announcing Housing Development Funding for Glens Falls and Watertown  I was thrilled to announce United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) funding for Glens Falls and Watertown. The Community Planning and Development Program Formula Allocations provide grants to states and local units of government to develop viable urban communities by providing decent housing and a suitable living environment, and by expanding economic opportunities, specifically for low- and moderate-income communities.  Glens Falls will receive $490,696 in funding and the City of Watertown will receive $920,779 in Community Development Block (CDBG) Grants, which will be used to support housing initiatives in both towns. Affordable housing is a prominent issue in many areas in my district, and initiatives like this help communities to provide more affordable and suitable opportunities. I will continue to advocate for programs that enable our local communities to support those in need of assistance. Read more here.   Writing an Op-Ed Commemorating the 40th Anniversary of the Miracle on Ice   This week, I wrote an op-ed commemorating the 40th anniversary of the iconic Miracle on Ice and celebrating the North Country’s rich Olympic history. The op-ed was published in The Sun this week. Read it here.  As always, thank you for subscribing to my weekly updates!    Sincerely,    Elise StefanikMember of Congress             Social Media Corner:       ___________________  Featured Read:   Times Union: State, federal lawmakers clash over access to DMV records      U.S. Rep. Elise Stefanik, R-Schuylerville, a staunch opponent of the Green Light Law, criticized Democrats for "absolutely [leaving] out federal agencies" as they decided to bar immigration officials from accessing DMV databases. Stefanik, whose district abuts the Canadian border, argued that federal officials must access DMV records to check license plates and stop possible criminals from crossing international lines – though she did not draw a connection explicitly between a lack of access to DMV databases and applications for travel perks.  "New York state should repeal the Green Light Law," Stefanik, who is an enrollee in the Global Entry program, said in an interview Monday afternoon. "They should stop prioritizing illegal immigrants over law-abiding citizens."                   _______________  Constituent Services  Please contact my Glens Falls office at (518) 743-0964 if you would like help with:   Federal agencies. Purchasing U.S. flags. Military Academy Nominations. Tours and tickets for your visit to Washington, D.C. Internships. And other resources.  Glens Falls Office  5 Warren Street, Suite 4  Glens Falls, NY 12801  _________________  Weekly Legislative Recap  Below find a list of legislation that the House of Representatives voted on this week.  H.R.1494 - Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) Homeland Security Partnerships Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  S.2107 - Protecting America's Food and Agriculture Act (Passed by Voice Vote) H.R.5273 - Securing America's Ports Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  H.R.504 - DHS Field Engagement Accountability Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  H.R.4737 - Department of Homeland Security Climate Change Research Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  H.R.4432 - Protecting Critical Infrastructure Against Drones and Emerging Threats Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  H.R.4753 - Drone Origin Security Enhancement Act (Passed by Voice Vote)  H.R.2932 - Homeland Security for Children Act (Passed 374 - 11, I voted Yes)  H.R.3413 - DHS Acquisition Reform Act of 2019 (Passed 380 - 4, I voted Yes) H.R.1980 - Smithsonian Women's History Museum Act (Passed 374 - 37; I voted Yes)  H.R.2546 - Protecting America's Wilderness Act (Passed 231 - 183; I voted No)  H.J.Res.79 - Removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment (Passed 232 - 183; I voted No)                   Washington, DC  318 Cannon H.O.B.Washington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4611Fax: (202) 226-0621 Glens Falls 5 Warren Street, Suite 4Glens Falls, NY 12801Phone: (518) 743-0964Fax: (518) 743-1391 Watertown88 Public SquareSuite AWatertown, NY 13601Phone: (315) 782-3150Fax: (315) 782-1291 Plattsburgh Office 137 Margaret StreetSuite 100Plattsburgh, NY 12901Phone: (518) 561-2324Fax: (518) 561-2408          Unsubscribe - Privacy

body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }         News from Representative Courtney                                                 Dear Cormack,  Following a busy week in Washington, here with a few updates on several priorities for eastern Connecticut.    Honoring Those Lost on 10th Anniversary of Kleen Energy Explosion  Last Friday marked ten years since the tragic explosion at the Kleen Energy Systems power plant in Middletown. The blast injured dozens of workers, and it took the lives of six: Peter Chepulis, Raymond Dobratz, Kenneth Haskell, Roy Rushton, Chris Walters, and one of my close friends, Ron Crabb. On Sunday, I was in Middletown along with colleagues, community leaders, and friends and family of those who were lost in the tragic accident, to honor and remember those who never came home that day. Ten years ago, workplace safety laws failed these six individuals, and the dozens of others who were injured in the blast. Nothing can ever make up for the lives lost that day, but we have a responsibility as a community and as a Congress to ensure we do all we can to protect America’s workers. Last year, on the 9th anniversary of the explosion, I introduced the Protecting America’s Workers Act (PAWA) to strengthen and modernize the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 (OSHA) – which hasn’t been meaningfully updated by Congress in over 50 years. The bill is simple, and contains some common-sense measures like improving whistleblower protections; requiring the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) to investigate all cases of death and series injuries that occur within a place of employment; and establishing rights for families of workers who were killed on the job by giving them the right to meet with OSHA investigators, receive copies of citations, and more. The lives lost ten years ago deserve to be honored with action. To read how PAWA makes workplaces safer, click here to visit my website.        Rep. Courtney joined community leaders, friends, and families at a memorial service for those lost in the Kleen Energy explosion     Bipartisan Action on Surprise Health Care Billing  Surprise medical bills are a crisis waiting to happen for so many families in eastern Connecticut and across the country. When people are ill, the last thing they should have to worry about is how to safeguard themselves against complex billing technicalities that result in surprise, sky-high medical bills. The cost of health care is a top-line issue for folks in our region, and surprise billing is a major contributor – my office has received far too many calls from people in eastern Connecticut who have not been treated fairly.  We’ve already taken steps in the House to curb the cost of prescription medication, and this week we took on surprise billing. On Tuesday, my colleagues and I on the house Education & Labor Committee voted to approve the bipartisan Ban Surprise Billing Act (H.R. 5800), a bill that would protect patients from devastating surprise medical bills, and would finally give them the financial confidence and peace of mind they deserve. These protections would be for everyone – for people who receive health care through their employer, and for those who are enrolled in the individual market. Erica Moser did a great job covering the ins and outs of the bill in her article for The Day, click here to read more. One of the most exciting parts about H.R. 5800 is that it’s so bipartisan – it was supported by both the Democratic Chairman of the Committee, and by the Republican Ranking Member. People in Congressional Districts across America are impacted by surprise medical bills, and it’s great to see Members from both sides of the aisle coming together to address the problem. I commend Chairman Scott and Ranking Member Foxx for working together to advance this bipartisan bill, I was proud to support it, and I’m looking forward to voting to pass it when it comes before the House for a final vote.        Click here to watch Rep. Courtney's remarks in favor of H.R. 5800     Meeting with National Defense University Students  On Tuesday, I hosted a large group of students from the National Defense University’s Eisenhower School to discuss some of the top priorities on the horizon for our Armed Forces and the industrial base, and to learn more about their work as students focusing on undersea warfare. As always, these NDU students were totally impressive – they came to study in Washington from all across the U.S., represented a variety of branches, backgrounds, agencies, and experiences, and were sharp and well informed on our national security strategy and priorities.   Our conversation turned in large part to the flurry of activity we’ve seen in Connecticut’s defense manufacturing sector recently. Up and down the supply chain, skilled manufacturers and small companies are seeing new opportunities for work. Connecticut’s defense manufacturing is booming, but even that good news presents its own challenges – mainly, how can we make sure that we have a workforce that’s skilled and well educated enough to take advantage of these new opportunities? The answer to that question has been the Eastern Connecticut Workforce Investment Board’s revolutionary job skills training program, the Manufacturing Pipeline Initiative (MPI). The MPI was kick-started with a $6 million federal grant that I helped to procure back in 2015, and since then it’s flourished alongside our state’s burgeoning manufacturing sector. The MPI has helped Electric Boat (EB) to grow by thousands of employees in just a few short years. In the last year alone, EB reported that they made over 1,000 hires directly from the pipeline. The MPI is exactly what was needed to fill the ranks of a booming manufacturing sector, and its been a total success for our region. It was great to host this impressive class of National Defense University students in Washington this week, and to discuss with them all of the moving parts that must work in unison to deliver the tools are Navy and Armed Forces need.        Students from the National Defense University met with Rep. Courtney at his Washington, DC office       The Start of a Months-Long Budget Process   Earlier this week, the White House released their official 2021 budget request. Ultimately it is Congress’s job to craft and pass a budget through the House and the Senate, and it’s the President's job to sign it. However, the start of the budget negotiation process typically begins with the White House’s budget request – their “proposed budget” – and this year we’re off to a strange start.  The White House’s proposed budget makes $1.1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid, Medicare and other health care programs over the next 10 years. It also slashes investments that help workers find and keep good paying jobs, and altogether eliminates bedrock programs that help fund America’s public education system. Thankfully, this is just the start of a months-long budget negotiation process. The proposed budget introduced by the White House yesterday has already received criticism from both sides of the aisle, and it’s not going to make it through Congress as-is. It’s not encouraging to see the White House kick the process off with a budget proposal that points so many important programs in the wrong direction, but as the House moves into our own budget negotiating process, we have an opportunity to work together across the aisle to get it right. It will remain our top priority in the House to protect and defend the health, financial security, and well-being of millions of Americans as we begin debate on the 2021 budget.      Proposed Shipbuilding Budget Receives Bipartisan Criticism  One of the components of the 2021 budget request that has generated significant bipartisan concern is the plan to cut back on shipbuilding investment for our Navy. Congress had traditionally worked together to provide strong support for the Navy’s plans to build, modernize and support a strong fleet of ships, submarines, destroyers and other vessels critical to our national defense. Contrary to expectations, however, the budget we received this week took a significant step backwards – proposing to purchase just 7 ships, a sharp reduction from the 10 that the Trump Administration itself planned for this year and a nearly 20% reduction in the budget for shipbuilding. Incredibly, one of the cuts included the reduction of a Virginia-class submarine, with only one requested in 2021. This plan flies in the face of more than a decade of testimony from our defense leaders about the unmatched value of our submarine force and increasing alarm about shortfalls in the fleet. It’s even in direct contradiction with the Trump Administration's own plans for our Navy and defense strategy. Given that every submarine we build will be in service for four decades, the decision to plan for only one new submarine next year is short-sighted. As Chairman of the House Seapower and Projection Forces Subcommittee, I can say with certainly that this budget is dead on arrival. Throughout the week, bipartisan concern about this proposal has grown across Congress and I am working with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to dig into this surprising plan as we begin our work on the 2021 budget. Click here to read about some of my efforts, and the bipartisan reaction to the budget.        Click here to read Rep. Courtney's bipartisan letter to Secretary Esper     Thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly eNewsletter. It’s an honor every day to represent eastern Connecticut, and I’m grateful that you’ve made my weekly update a part of your weekly routine. I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work – if you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139. Have a great weekend,                                Joe CourtneyMember of Congress                     OFFICE LOCATIONS        Washington, DC Office 2332 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2076Fax: (202) 225-4977 Norwich Office 55 Main Street, Suite 250Norwich, CT 06360Phone: (860) 886-0139Fax: (860) 886-2974 Enfield Office 77 Hazard Ave, Unit JEnfield, CT 06082Phone: (860) 741-6011Fax: (860) 741-6036           | Privacy Policy           p { margin-bottom:1em; } /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { body, td, div, span, p {font-size:40px !important;} a { text-decoration:none; } *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} *[class*="footer"] td { font-size: 12px !important;} *[class*="mobileimg"] { width: 300px !important;} *[class*="mobile-hidden"] { display:none !important; } *[class*="mobileshare"] img { width: 288 !important; height: 50 !important;} }

Safe travels back to the Natural State! The House convened and voted on a series of bills, including the Homeland Security for Children Act (), the DHS Acquisition Reform Act of 2019 (), the providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2546) to designate certain lands in the State of Colorado as components of the National Wilderness Preservation System, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the joint resolution () removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment; and for other purposes. (), the Smithsonian Women's History Museum Act (), the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act (), and the removing the deadline for the ratification of the equal rights amendment (). Budget season has officially begun. Earlier this week, I received the President’s budget request for Fiscal Year 2021. While Congress holds the Article I powers of the Constitution, or the “power of the purse,” the President’s budget outlines his vision for the nation. The release of the President’s budget request historically kicks off the congressional budget process in both the House and the Senate. It serves as a starting point for lawmakers to make spending decisions and analyze the economic outlook for the coming year. The framework of the budget process can be divided up into :   President submits the budget to Congress House and Senate mark up and pass budget House and Senate conference the budget resolution Consideration and passage of Appropriations bills Consideration of reconciliation/authorization Start of new Fiscal Year (October 1st)   I applaud President Trump for putting forward a budget proposal. That’s more than we can say for the People’s House, where, for the second straight year, the Democrat majority has failed to produce a budget. That’s not leadership.  This is interesting to me because, on the House Budget Committee majority’s website, there is a section titled “Responsibility.” The first sentence in this section reads, “The Committee’s chief responsibility is to draft an annual concurrent resolution on the budget that provides a congressional framework for spending and revenue levels, the federal surplus or deficit, and public debt.”  In every business, in every city, in every state, a budget is done. Yet, here in the House, in the greatest country in the world, we’re not doing a budget. Simply put, a failure to budget is a failure to govern.  We must start doing our job to put our country on a sustainable, responsible fiscal path. This is our duty to the American people, not promoting budget-busting policies, including Medicare-for-All and the Green New Deal, that will leave future generations saddled with the consequences of House Democrats’ eagerness to spend with no way to pay. It’s time for Democrats to stop punting one of our most basic responsibilities in Congress. I’m ready for them to join us at the table to do the difficult work.  While we can’t analyze the Democrats’ budget – because they won’t put one forth – the House Budget Committee did hold a hearing on the President’s FY 2021 budget proposal with OMB Acting Director Russell Vought. As we discussed, the proposal seeks to balance our fiscal constraints with the need to fund the priorities of the country, including national defense. The President’s budget includes deficit reduction measures, specifically $4.6 trillion between 2021-2030. This is a strong start, but more work remains to be done to put our country on a solid fiscal path. Moving forward, it is imperative that we work together in a bipartisan, bicameral fashion to advance a budget that funds our nation’s important priorities while acknowledging our very real fiscal challenges. You can read my full opening remarks .  MEETINGS  In between votes and legislative business, I also had the opportunity to meet with organizations from the Natural State! It was a pleasure to meet with Keturah Finch and Tanner Arnwine of Bentonville to talk about neurofibromatosis (NF), a genetic, tumor-generating disorder. We discussed research through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program (CDMRP) and the National Institutes of Health, as well as its value to civilians, warfighters, and veterans suffering from NF. Novel research has led to a new era of medical breakthroughs for a variety of illnesses, but there is still much more work to be done across many fields. We must continue to make smart investments that build our pipeline of science, research, and medical discovery. The next morning, I invited my Republican House Budget Committee colleagues to join me at the Office of Budget and Management to hear more about the President’s recently released budget proposal, as well as fiscal priorities of the White House. As I mentioned earlier, I appreciate the Administration for drafting a budget. Congress should be doing the same thing, but House Democrats have refused to put forth a proposal yet again. In the real world, everyday Americans and Arkansans are held accountable for their income, expenses, and savings. Main Street job creators and business leaders are held accountable for demonstrating fiscal restraint, for making tough choices, and for setting priorities. Congress should not be any different. But in the House, Democrats are refusing to put forth the very document that tells us what we need to know about how much we’re spending, what we’re raising in revenue, and the impact of our deficits and debt on our economy and the nation. The American people deserve better.  Representatives from NorthWest Arkansas Community College (NWACC) were in Washington, and I had the opportunity to hear some important school and curriculum updates. We talked about enhancing Career and Technical Education (CTE), the Fostering Undergraduate Talent by Unlocking Resources for Education (FUTURE) Act – which I voted for – and the National Science Foundation’s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program. NWACC just received an ATE grant for a project that will create a Technical Certificate in Integrated Design to help expand the skilled technical workforce, especially in construction fields and engineering design. NWACC is helping prepare our students for the jobs of today and the future, and I appreciate their dedication to providing quality education and opportunities in the Third District. I thank Dr. Evelyn Jorgenson, Dr. Ricky Tompkins, Jim Hall, Rachel Harris, and DeAnne Witherspoon for their time and work!  I then met with the Arkansas Fraternal Order of Police. I always appreciate meeting with our law enforcement officers and hearing more about their work to protect and serve our communities. We discussed many issues, including The Protect and Serve Act (HR 1325). I’m a cosponsor of this legislation, which creates new federal penalties for individuals who deliberately attack or attempt to cause significant bodily injury to any law enforcement officer. This bill aims to deter attacks against police officers who have increasingly been targeted and face higher levels of hostility because of the uniform they wear. I’m extremely thankful for the work of the men and women who wear the badge each day!  My next meeting was with the Enlisted Association of the Arkansas National Guard. It was wonderful to sit down with Arkansas National Guard members from Fort Smith and other parts of the state to talk about their work, duties, and programs that support their efforts. We also had a productive discussion on the National Guard’s role going forward in the Space and Cyber domains. The Arkansas Air National Guard has both Space and Cyber missions. As a 30-year veteran of the Arkansas Army National Guard, I salute their service and thank them for their commitment to the Natural State and our nation! I then welcomed Dr. John Lorsch, Director of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, to my office to speak about the Institutional Development Award (IDea) program and its impact on Arkansas. Our conversations focused on the NIH’s research and biomedical investments within the Natural State.  I wrapped up the day at the National Guard Association, where I joined National Guard members from across the country to talk about defense efforts, legislative advocacy, and my work on the House Budget Committee. I shared stories about my time in uniform, as well as my perspectives on appropriations work in Congress. I talked about the constrained resource environment we face, and how growing mandatory spending is squeezing the portion of discretionary funding available for national priorities. The Guard brings great value to the fight, and it was my honor to talk to this great group and answer questions.  The next morning, I met with Dan Hendrix, President and CEO of the World Trade Center Arkansas. I appreciated an update on their work, economic development in the community, small business grants, and the impact of recent trade deals on the state. Arkansas is a state of opportunity, and the World Trade Center Arkansas is a pivotal resource that has supported bilateral trade services, global connections, and export development programs for local businesses.  Our region is full of opportunity, and it was great to speak with students from the Future Leaders Exchange (FLEX) program. FLEX students spend an academic year in the U.S. living with a volunteer host family and attending high school. The students, who are from Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, are currently living and going to school in Russellville and Springdale! They said that they have learned a lot during their time living and studying in the region – and that they love the sense of community in Arkansas!    Modernized infrastructure is vital to keeping our communities economically competitive and strong. It was great to wrap up my week in Washington with Department of Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao. We had very productive conversations on rural infrastructure grants, local projects like I-49 and regional airport improvements, and budget and appropriations. We also highlighted the importance of addressing U.S. infrastructure needs using smart and effective methods that provide results and maximize our resources. Today, I also want to wish everyone – especially my wonderful wife, Terri – a Happy Valentine’s Day! I'm grateful that my office was able to present some special valentines to residents at Methodist Village Senior Living in Fort Smith. Spreading some cheer and happiness is what this day is all about! I’m looking forward to being back in the district and traveling the Natural State next week. Wishing everyone a Happy Presidents’ Day on Monday! Let us reflect and honor the leaders who've held our nation's highest office to serve the American people. By swearing an oath to “preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States,” they each answered the call to lead our great country throughout history. From George Washington to Donald Trump, Happy Presidents' Day to all our leaders – past and present!  Remember to keep an eye on my  or check out my Twitter and Instagram pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington.     From the front... This harmful plan allows states to receive a waiver to block grant their Medicaid programs for certain low-income Medicaid recipients, and would have the impact of weakening the entire program and pushing Medicaid recipients off their much-needed, life-saving health care coverage. These block grants are just the latest in a slew of attempts by this Administration to gut the Affordable Care Act—and the numerous coverage expansions that it has offered to millions of Americans, of all ages and backgrounds, who were unable to gain affordable coverage before—and the millions more who could gain coverage in my home state of Texas expands Medicaid. I am proud that my resolution demonstrated our Democratic majority’s strong opposition to removing the expanded protections that the Affordable Care Act provided to primarily childless adults and those parents who are living at or below the poverty line.                Watch my video condemning this Administration’s latest assault on affordable and accessible health care.      Millions of hard-working Americans have finally been able to gain affordable health insurance—now the Trump administration wants to take away the progress made by these Americans—and undercut access to health care. And they also want to chip away at access to health care for millions of Americans who have and will be able to gain coverage through state Medicaid expansions.  That is why I am proud to lead this resolution, and I am proud to fight for affordable and accessible health care each and every day.  Sincerely,    Marc Veasey  P.s. line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     A transformative plan to undertake projects that are smarter, safer, and made to last.‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌            Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window Click here to open a plain text version of this email                  HOME ABOUT ME NEWS CONSTITUENT SERVICES ISSUES CONTACT ME          MOVING AMERICA AND THE ENVIRONMENT FORWARD The need to invest in our crumbling infrastructure is clear and so is our responsibility to reduce carbon pollution in the transportation sector. To that end, as Chairman of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, I recently joined House leadership in unveiling the Moving Forward Framework – a five-year, $760 billion investment in infrastructure that would­ fix some of the country’s most urgent infrastructure needs. From addressing the massive road and transit maintenance backlog, to designing safer streets, to putting the U.S. on a path toward zero emissions from the transportation sector and increasing resiliency, the Moving Forward Framework charts a course for investment and reform. The framework put forth will transform the federal role in helping communities around the country undertake projects that are smarter, safer, and made to last.        LEARN MORE ABOUT THE FRAMEWORK    Our country has changed dramatically since the 1950s, yet people and goods are now literally stuck trying to move on transportation networks developed nearly 70 years ago. It’s past time for transformational investments to make our infrastructure smarter, safer, and resilient to climate change, or else we will keep throwing money at an antiquated system that is only holding us and our economy back. The Moving Forward Framework is the launchpad we need to get our existing infrastructure working again and create an estimated 10 million jobs, while reducing  carbon pollution, dramatically improving safety, and spurring economic activity. In the coming months, I look forward to continuing our work to make this framework a reality. The cost of inaction is too great.  The transportation sector is the single largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the United States. That is why I am writing comprehensive legislation that will meaningfully tackle carbon pollution by funding more and better transit service, expanding Amtrak’s passenger rail services, requiring states to report on greenhouse gas emissions, and focusing on maintaining what we have rather than building new and bigger highways.  This framework invests in alternative modes of transportation, such as cycling, walking, and public transportation, to get Americans to work safely while reducing congestion and our carbon footprint.  In addition to combatting carbon pollution, safety will be front and center to this legislation. Last year more than 37,000 people died on American roads, and the number of pedestrians and cyclists killed has risen at a startling rate. The Moving Forward Framework will invest $10 billion in road safety over the next five years and will require states to prioritize safety when planning projects. The Moving Forward Framework marks an exciting and necessary shift in how the United States plans, builds, and maintains its infrastructure. Putting carbon pollution, safety, and improvements to bring our existing infrastructure up to a state of good repair first will help our communities make better investments that reflect the needs and desires of the American public.  Investing in Oregon’s Ports and Harbors I am excited to announce that I have secured nearly $11 million in new funds from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to support dredging at the ports of Coos Bay, Siuslaw, Gold Beach, and the Coquille River. These dredging projects are vital to supporting the economic health of coastal communities and ensuring the safety of mariners. Without routine dredging, these ports would quickly fill in with silt, become unsafe and eventually unusable.  The recent funding is just a down payment on much larger needs on the Oregon Coast, including repairs and improvements on jetties at most coastal ports. That’s why earlier this year I introduced legislation which passed the House to ensure that the USACE fully utilizes all revenues from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund for its intended purpose: harbor maintenance.  I am currently drafting and plan to pass later this year a new Water Resources Development Act (WRDA), which will make sure Oregon harbors receive their fair share of the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund, improve dam safety, and ensure greater resilience from climate change. With the passage of WRDA, we can ensure that Oregon’s ports receive the dredging and jetty repair funds they need. Fighting for Clean Water The Trump administration is moving forward with two proposals that will have long-lasting impacts on our public health and environment, as well as cost taxpayers more money in the long run. First, the Trump administration recently released its final “Dirty Water Rule,” the single largest effort to rollback clean water protections in our nation’s history. Access to clean water is a right, not a privilege. However, the Trump administration is rolling back decades-old Clean Water Act protections that aim to make our rivers and streams safe for fishing and swimming,  including eliminating protections for thousands of miles of small streams, leaving half of our nation’s wetlands at risk for destruction, and putting the drinking water of over 117 million people at risk. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has estimated that the Dirty Water Rule will eliminate clean water protections on between 18 to 71 percent of the nation’s stream and river miles, and over 50 percent of wetlands. Yet, in spite of my repeated requests, EPA political appointees have refused to quantify the exact scope and nature of waters that will lose Clean Water Act protections – failing to let communities know if the Dirty Water Rule could harm or destroy locally-important waterbodies. The Trump administration also announced in early January that it is moving forward with plans to amend the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) to, among other things, allow Federal agencies to ignore the impacts of climate change when developing and planning infrastructure projects. When tackling new and critical infrastructure projects across the country, we need to consider the range of impacts to our environment. Pretending like our climate isn’t changing is reckless and costly.  NEPA ensures the environmental impacts of a proposed project are examined and that the public has a role in the decision-making process. Not only is weakening NEPA requirements a bad idea for public health and the environment, but it will end up costing taxpayers more when projects aren’t built to be resilient. Unfortunately, this administration has consistently put the interests of industry first and appears hell-bent on taking us back to an era when our nation’s rivers were so polluted, they caught on fire and the Willamette River was an open sewer. Americans deserve better. I will continue to use all the tools at my disposal to stop the Trump Administration from its reckless rollbacks of our clean water protections and considerations of climate change when planning Federal infrastructure projects. Yvette D. Clarke's DHS Climate Change Research Act  in the House of Representatives   Last night, my bill, H.R. 4737, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Climate Change Research Act passed in the U.S. House of Representatives. The DHS Climate Change Research Act takes important action to address America’s national security concerns in the face of our changing climate. Climate Change is not only an existential threat to our planet, it is also a major national security risk to Americans at home and abroad. Today, more than ever, it is critical that we understand both the impacts that climate change is having across the globe, as well as the implications of these impacts to our national security. Specifically, the DHS Climate Change Research Act will:    ensure that the Department of Homeland Security fulfills its mission of conducting research to advance homeland security; direct the Science and Technology Directorate to conduct analysis and technological research on how DHS can confront climate change; implement a high level of accountability to the American public by mandating annual reporting to Congress regarding the research and projects that DHS has undertaken in the previous year.  It is critical that we address the homeland security implications of climate change in greater depth. I am happy that Congress took bold steps to addressing this crisis by passing my critical legislation which safeguards communities across the nation from future climate impacts.           Washington, D.C. Office 2058 Rayburn House Office BuildingWashington, D.C. 20515Phone: (202) 225-6231  Brooklyn Office 222 Lenox Road, Suites 1 & 2Brooklyn, NY 11226Phone: (718) 287-1142            Stay Connected    Unsubscribe
